quoteFirst: Although we had not the knowledge of this accident to add to our troubles, that night in Bioto Creek, which we spent cramped up in the most uncomfortable position, was probably the most unenviable I have ever passed. Darkness fell at 6.30; at 3.30 A.M. we were very glad to welcome the moonrise, and saw the light gradually silhouette the dense matted branches of the mangrove.
quoteLast: we left our anchorage, and the dawn saw us well on our voyage to Pokama. It was wonderful on our arrival there how soon, under the influence of a good bath, clean clothes, a white table-cloth, and a decent meal, we forgot the horrors of the night that had just passed.
title:
Two Years Among New Guinea Cannibals
A Naturalist's Sojourn Among the Aborigines of Unexplored New Guinea
author: Pratt, A. E. (Antwerp Edgar), 1852-1924; Pratt, Henry [Annotator]

quoteLast: on the 19th an attack was made on the pickets of the First brigade near Cupp's ford, which attack, coupled with the firing on the extreme left of the infantry line, alarmed the camps, and everything was got ready for immediate action. The First brigade was at once ordered to the support of its picket line, while the Reserve brigade, which had the night before received orders to make a reconnoissance on the Middle road, was ordered to halt and await further orders.
title:
Personal Recollections of a Cavalryman
With Custer's Michigan Cavalry Brigade in the Civil War
author: Kidd, James Harvey, 1840-1913

quoteLast: next morning, and were relieved to find them nearly full, and the water drinkable. The rain came down in torrents shortly afterwards.
title: From Pekin to Calais by Land
author: De Windt, Harry, 1856-1933

quoteFirst: When we left Bellagio, the two Misses Hawker, often our companions in Rome, accompanied us. We ascended the Splugen from Chiavenna in pitch darkness, till,
quoteLast: , the diligence entered upon the snow cuttings, and we proceeded for some time between walls of snow, often fifteen feet high. At last we stopped altogether, and in a spot where there was no refuge whatever from the ferocious ice-laden wind.
title: The Story of My Life, volumes 1-3
author: Hare, Augustus J. C. (Augustus John Cuthbert), 1834-1903

quoteLast: , the engine-room became the center of interest, but in spite of every effort the water still gained. Lashly and Williams, up to their necks in rushing water, stuck gamely to the work of clearing suctions, and for a time, with donkey engine and bilge pump sucking, it looked as if the water might be got under.
title: The Voyages of Captain Scott : Retold from the Voyage of the Discovery and Scott's Last Expedition
author: Turley, Charles, 1868-1940

quoteFirst: When the last couple was married, the festival was over, and dancing, singing and feasting lasted long into the night. I had forgotten all about time, the water barrels and Father’s order to come right back to the ship. By the position of the moon I guessed it was
quoteLast: A frightened cry from a native running up from the beach broke in on the revelry. Wildly he pointed to the ship off shore. The truck driver who never had much to say at any time laconically observed:
title: The cradle of the deep

quoteFirst: A yawning boy, sweeping out the store, gazed with open mouth as, hot and perspiring from my run, I hurried in and rushed to the booth. In a moment I had the office and the night editor’s desk, had told him who I was, and began to dictate. “At
quoteLast: by our time (see what time Paris time is for that, and put it in) a French battleship was sunk by the man who is to stop all war. Probably no one on board escaped.
title: The Man Who Ended War
author: Godfrey, Hollis, 1874-1936; Grunwald, Charles, 1867-1910 [Illustrator]
